thread.title: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks Score Strongest Gain In 2 Weeks
thread.title_full: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks Score Strongest Gain In 2 Weeks

author: morningstar.com
title: EUROPE MARKETS: European Stocks Score Strongest Gain In 2 Weeks
text:
By Carla Mozee and Victor Reklaitis, MarketWatch
SABMiller leaps on M&A approach
Europe's blue-chips benchmark on Wednesday scored its best session in about two weeks, helped by deal news in the beer industry.
The Stoxx Europe 600 rose 1.5% to end at 361.87, joining U.S. and Asian markets in a move higher. The advance was the pan-European index's largest since Sept. 3, FactSet data showed.
Shooting to the top of the index was SABMiller PLC (SAB.JO) (SAB.JO), closing up 19.9% in London after the British brewer of Miller Genuine Draft and other brands attracted a takeover approach from rival Anheuser-Busch InBev NV (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/sabmiller-gets-takeover-approach-frm-ab-inbev-2015-09-16)
Belgian-Brazilian brewer AB InBev (ABI.BT) (ABI.BT), whose brands include Budweiser and Corona, saw its shares finish up 6.4% in Brussels.
"Any merger that did not involve truly massive disposals in order gain competition clearance would create an extremely large, global brewer," Mark Brumby, analyst at Langton Capital, wrote in a note. "Customers may complain and competition authorities the world over may be sharpening their pencils but we would assume that a significant amount of planning has gone into the proposed deal and we await details with interest."
Danish brewer Carlsberg A/S rose 4.7% and Dutch brewer Heineken International NV (HEIO.AE) picked up 3.6%.
The leap in SABMiller shares contributed to a 1.5% rise in the U.K.'s FTSE 100 (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ftse-100-on-track-for-best-session-in-a-week-2015-09-16) to 6,229.21.
Fed watch: European stocks started Wednesday's session higher in the wake of a push-up in Chinese stocks, which surged by the most in nearly three weeks (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/asian-stock-markets-bounce-back-ahead-of-fed-meeting-2015-09-16). That followed Tuesday's jump in U.S. stocks , with some analysts attributing the move on a thin-volume day to expectations the Fed will leave interest rates at their record low levels. U.S. stocks on Wednesday (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/investors-avoid-big-bets-with-fed-confab-starting-us-stock-futures-flat-2015-09-16) were modestly gaining.
The central bank's two-day policy meeting will conclude Thursday with an interest-rate decision.
Investors on Wednesday received the U.S. Labor Department's report showing the cost of consumer goods fell in August (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/inflation-falls-for-first-time-since-january-cpi-data-show-2015-09-16), leaving the consumer price index down by a seasonally adjusted 0.1%. That marked the first decline since January.
The data were "unlikely to be a game changer, as the overall U.S. inflation picture does not cry out for higher interest rates," said Angus Campbell, senior analyst at FxPro, in a note before the CPI report was released.
Separately, inflation in the eurozone unexpectedly fell in August (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/eurozone-inflation-falls-unexpectedly-in-august-2015-09-16-54853932), with the annual rate of inflation downwardly revised to 0.1% from an initial estimate of 0.2%.
France's CAC 40 popped up 1.7% to end at 4,645.84. In Paris trade, shares of Orange SA (ORA.FR) rose 2.9% after the telecom company's stock was raised to buy from hold at Deutsche Bank. In Frankfurt, the DAX 30 closed up 0.4% to 10,227.21
In currencies trading (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/us-dollar-weakens-against-yen-euro-ahead-of-fed-decision-2015-09-16), the pound jumped 1% to $1.5495 after U.K. jobs data for July showed wages for British workers rose at the fastest pace in more than six years (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/uk-wages-rise-to-six-year-high-2015-09-16-54851243). The increase may put some pressure on the Bank of England to consider raising interest rates sooner than later. The pound traded as high as $1.5529 after the jobs data.
Movers: SAP SE (SAP.XE) gained 1.7% following an ratings upgrade to overweight from neutral at J.P. Morgan. The German software maker has made it through the toughest part of its cloud transition, and "margins will trough this year and then gradually increase" about 50 basis points to 60 basis points each year over the next five years, said analyst Stacy Pollard in a research note.
Inditex (ITX.MC), the company behind fashion retailer Zara, bounced up 5.9% as the company said a weaker euro helped sales rise 17% in the first half of its fiscal year (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/inditex-profit-boosted-by-weak-euro-2015-09-16-14853212). Profit climbed 26%.
Zodiac Aerospace (ZC.FR) shares slid 18.8% in the wake of a ratings cut to underweight from neutral at J.P. Morgan on the fifth profit warning in 12 months from the French supplier of aircraft equipment.
 16, 2015 12:14 ET (16:14
